docs.title: In this day, we focus on fundamental array operations that are commonly asked in coding interviews.
✅ Problem 1: Find Maximum Element in an Array
📌 Problem Statement
docs.text: Given an array of integers, find and return the maximum element present in the array.

docs.title: 💡 Approach
docs.text: We traverse the array once and keep track of the largest value seen so far.

docs.title: 🧠 Detailed Explanation
docs.text:
1. Assume the first element of the array is the maximum.
  2. Start traversing from the second element.
  3. Compare each element with the current maximum.
  4. If the current element is greater, update the maximum.
  5. After finishing traversal, the stored value is the maximum element.

This avoids unnecessary sorting and gives an optimal solution.

docs.title:
def find_max(arr):
    max_element = arr[0]

    for num in arr:
        if num > max_element:
            max_element = num

    return max_element
⏱ Time & Space Complexity
docs.text: Time Complexity: O(n) : We scan the array once where n is number of elements. Space Complexity: O(1) : No extra space is used.

docs.title: 📌 Problem Statement
docs.text: Given an array, reverse the elements and return the reversed array.

docs.title: 💡 Approach
docs.text: Use Python slicing to reverse the array.

docs.title: 🧠 Detailed Explanation
docs.text:
Python provides slicing which allows accessing elements in reverse order using [::-1].

Steps:

  1. Start from last index.
  2. Move backwards.
  3. Collect elements into a new array.

This produces a reversed array in a single step.

docs.title: 💻 Solution (Python)
docs.text:
def reverse_array(arr):
    return arr[::-1]

docs.title: ⏱ Time & Space Complexity
docs.text: Time Complexity: O(n) : Each element is accessed once. Space Complexity: O(n) : New reversed array is created.

docs.title: 🎯 Day 1 Completed Successfully! Practice both problems before moving to Day 2.
In this day, we learn one of the most powerful array techniques used in interviews — Two Pointers.
✅ Problem 1: Two Sum in a Sorted Array
📌 Problem Statement
docs.text:
Given a sorted array of integers and a target value, determine whether there exist two numbers such that their sum equals the target.

Return True if such a pair exists, otherwise return False.

docs.title: 💡 Approach
docs.text:
Since the array is sorted, we can use two pointers:

  • One pointer at the beginning.
  • One pointer at the end.

We adjust pointers based on the sum comparison.

docs.title: 🧠 Detailed Explanation
docs.text:
1. Initialize two pointers:
  2. left = 0
  3. right = len(arr) - 1
  4. Calculate the sum of elements at both pointers.
  5. If sum equals target → return True.
  6. If sum is less than target → move left pointer forward.
  7. If sum is greater than target → move right pointer backward.
  8. Continue until left < right.
  9. If no pair found → return False.

This works because the array is sorted.

docs.title:
def two_sum_sorted(arr, target):
    left = 0
    right = len(arr) - 1

    while left < right:
        current_sum = arr[left] + arr[right]

        if current_sum == target:
            return True
        elif current_sum < target:
            left += 1
        else:
            right -= 1

    return False
⏱ Time & Space Complexity
docs.text: Time Complexity: O(n) : Each element is visited at most once. Space Complexity: O(1) : No additional data structures used.

docs.title: ✅ Problem 2: Remove Duplicates from Sorted ArrayReverse an Array
📌 Problem Statement
docs.text: Given a sorted array, remove duplicates in-place such that each element appears only once. Return the number of unique elements.

docs.title: 💡 Approach
docs.text:
Use two pointers:

  • One pointer (i) keeps track of unique position.
  • Another pointer (j) scans the array.

docs.title: 🧠 Detailed Explanation
docs.text:
1. If the array is empty → return 0.
  2. Set pointer i = 0.
  3. Traverse from index 1 to end using pointer j.
  4. If arr[j] is different from arr[i]:
    • Increment i
    • Assign arr[i] = arr[j]
  5. After traversal, return i + 1. This ensures duplicates are overwritten.

docs.title: 💻 Solution (Python)
docs.text:
def remove_duplicates(arr):
    if not arr:
        return 0

    i = 0
    for j in range(1, len(arr)):
        if arr[j] != arr[i]:
            i += 1
            arr[i] = arr[j]

    return i + 1

docs.title: ⏱ Time & Space Complexity
docs.text: Time Complexity: O(n) : Single traversal of the array. Space Complexity: O(1) : In-place modification without extra space.

docs.title: 🎯 Day 2 Completed Successfully! Practice both problems before moving to Day 3.
In this day, we learn the Sliding Window technique, which helps optimize problems involving subarrays or continuous sequences.
✅ Problem 1: Maximum Sum Subarray of Size K
📌 Problem Statement
docs.text: Given an array of integers and a number k, find the maximum sum of any contiguous subarray of size k.

docs.title: 💡 Approach
docs.text:
Instead of calculating every subarray sum repeatedly (which is inefficient), we use a sliding window:

  • Calculate sum of first k elements.
  • Slide the window forward by removing the left element and adding the new right element.

docs.title: 🧠 Detailed Explanation
docs.text:
1. Compute the sum of first k elements.
  2. Store it as max_sum.
  3. Start from index k.
  4. Add current element to window.
  5. Subtract element that is leaving the window.
  6. Update max_sum.
  7. Continue until end of array.

This reduces unnecessary repeated summation.

docs.title:
def max_subarray_sum(arr, k):
    window_sum = sum(arr[:k])
    max_sum = window_sum

    for i in range(k, len(arr)):
        window_sum += arr[i]
        window_sum -= arr[i - k]
        max_sum = max(max_sum, window_sum)

    return max_sum
⏱ Time & Space Complexity
docs.text: Time Complexity: O(n) : Each element is processed once. Space Complexity: O(1) : Only variables are used.

docs.title: ✅ Problem 2: Longest Substring Without Repeating Characters
📌 Problem Statement
docs.text: Given a string, find the length of the longest substring without repeating characters.

docs.title: 💡 Approach
docs.text:
Use sliding window with a set:

  • Expand window by adding characters.
  • If duplicate found, shrink from left.
  • Track maximum length.

docs.title: 🧠 Detailed Explanation
docs.text:
1. Use two pointers left and right.
  2. Maintain a set to track characters in window.
  3. If character not in set → add it.
  4. If duplicate found → remove from left until unique.
  5. Update maximum length during traversal.

docs.title: 💻 Solution (Python)
docs.text:
def length_of_longest_substring(s):
    char_set = set()
    left = 0
    max_length = 0

    for right in range(len(s)):
        while s[right] in char_set:
            char_set.remove(s[left])
            left += 1

        char_set.add(s[right])
        max_length = max(max_length, right - left + 1)

    return max_length

docs.title: ⏱ Time & Space Complexity
docs.text: Time Complexity: O(n) : Each character is visited at most twice. Space Complexity: O(min(n, m)) : Set stores unique characters.
